Situation1: They see a swimmer struggling near the middle of the pool and need to stay vigilant to respond quickly.
Expectation2: Participate in community service and charity work
Situation2: A monthly food drive for the local homeless shelter is scheduled to take place at the convent today.
Story: I sat in my high chair by the pool, whistle around my neck, eyes scanning the shimmering water. The sun was hot, and the kids were loud, but my focus never wavered. As a lifeguard, I knew every second counted. Suddenly, I noticed a boy in the middle of the pool, his strokes faltering, head bobbing awkwardly. My muscles tensed, ready to leap in if he slipped under. But my phone buzzed in my pocket—a reminder from the convent. Today was the monthly food drive, and I was expected to help prepare and distribute meals for the homeless. Sister Maria’s words echoed in my mind: “We must serve with our hands and our hearts.” Guilt gnawed at me. The sisters were counting on me, and the people at the shelter needed every helping hand. But here, at the pool, these swimmers depended on my vigilance. I felt torn, my heart pulled in two directions, the weight of both uniforms pressing down on me as I watched the struggling boy and thought of the hungry waiting at the convent.
